(or for such shorter period that the registrant was required to submit and post

<P STYLE="font: 11pt/115% Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 
10pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font: 11pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center"><B><U>Explanatory Note</U></B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center; text-indent: 0.5in"><B>&nbsp;</B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 11pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 
0.5in">The purpose of this Amendment No.&nbsp;1 to
the registrant&rsquo;s Quarterly Report on Form&nbsp;10-Q for the quarter ended 
June 30, 2013, filed with the Securities and Exchange
Commission on August 19, 2013 (the &ldquo;Form 10-Q&rdquo;), is solely to
furnish Exhibit 101 to the Form&nbsp;10-Q.&nbsp;&nbsp;Exhibit
101 provides the financial statements and related notes from the Form&nbsp;10-Q 
formatted in XBRL (Extensible Business Reporting
Language).</P>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center; text-indent: 0.5in"><B>&nbsp;</B></P>
<P STYLE="font: 11pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 
0.5in">No other changes have been made to the Form&nbsp;10-Q.
This Amendment No.&nbsp;1 to the Form&nbsp;10-Q speaks as of the original filing
date of the Form 10-Q, does not reflect events
that may have occurred subsequent to the original filing date and does not 
modify or update in any way disclosures made in the
original Form&nbsp;10-Q.</P>
<P STYLE="font: 11pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

gaap:OrganizationConsolidationAndPresentationOfFinancialStatementsDisclosureText
Block contextRef="From2013-01-01to2013-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt/115% Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 10pt"&gt;1. 
ORGANIZATION&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The company was incorporated under the laws of the state of
Nevada&#13;on December 18, 2008, with 75,000,000 authorized common shares with a
par value of $0.001. On January 3, 2013, the Company approved&#13;the action to 
amend and restate the Articles of Incorporation of the Company and increase the 
authorized common shares to 500,000,000&#13;and create and authorize 40,000,000 
shares of Preferred Stock which was approved by written consent of the holders 
representing&#13;approximately 67% of the outstanding voting securities of the 
Company. Series A Preferred Stock was created and designated with&#13;super-
voting rights of 100 votes per share of Series A Preferred Stock held, and is 
convertible into 10 shares of common stock&#13;for every share of preferred 
stock held.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company was 
initially organized for the purpose of acquiring&#13;and exploring mineral 
claims. The company acquired a mineral claim with unknown reserves. We intend to
continue to hold the mining&#13;claims, but will not be developing these assets 
during 2013.&amp;#160; For this reason, we are no longer classifying the Company
as&#13;an exploration stage company.&amp;#160; The Company has entered the sand 
and gravel extraction business with its joint venture in the&#13;state of 
Washington and expects to receive revenue from the joint venture during the 2013
fiscal year.&amp;#160; The future goal of&#13;the Company will be to develop a 
waste services division&amp;#160; The Company has modified its business plan to 
include the development&#13;of waste management services including the storage, 
recycling, and disposal of waste.&amp;#160; The Company does not presently 
have&#13;any waste management operations and is considered to be in the 
development stage, but due to our joint venture we expect to have&#13;revenues 
and adjust our classification as a development stage company to an operational 
stage company as sales are made.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:OrganizationConsolidationAndPresentationOfFinancialStatementsDisclosureText
Block>
    <us-gaap:LiquidityDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2013-01-01to2013-06-
30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;2. 
GOING CONCERN&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The accompanying financial statements 
have been prepared assuming&#13;that the company will continue as a going 
concern. The company does not have sufficient working capital for its planned 
activity,&#13;and to service its debt, which raises substantial doubt about its 
ability to continue as a going concern. The Company has incurred&#13;accumulated
losses of $2,407,487 since inception (December 18, 2008) through June 30, 
2013.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; 
margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Continuation of the company as a going 
concern is dependent upon&#13;obtaining additional working capital and the 
management of the company has developed a strategy which it believes will 
accomplish&#13;this objective through short term loans from an officer-director,
and additional equity investments, which will enable the company&#13;to continue
operations for the coming year. These financial statements do not include any 
adjustments relating to the recoverability&#13;and classification of recorded 
asset amounts, or amounts and classification of liabilities that might result 
from this uncertainty.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:LiquidityDisclosureTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock contextRef="From2013-01-
01to2013-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;3. SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin:
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Basis of Preparation&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Pursuant to the rules and regulations of the 
Securities and Exchange&#13;Commission for Form 10-Q, the financial statements, 
footnote disclosures and other information normally included in financial 
statements&#13;prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting 
principles have been condensed or omitted. The financial statements 
contained&#13;in this report are unaudited but, in the opinion of management, 
reflect all adjustments, consisting of only normal recurring 
adjustments,&#13;necessary for a fair presentation of the interim financial 
statements. The results of operations for any interim period are 
not&#13;necessarily indicative of results for the full year. The balance sheet 
as at December 31, 2012 has been derived from audited financial&#13;statements 
at that date but does not include all of the information and footnotes required 
by accounting principles generally accepted&#13;in the United States of America 
for complete financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The preparation of financial statements in 
conformity with accounting&#13;principles generally accepted in the United 
States requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the 
reported&#13;amounts of assets and liabilities, disclosure of contingent assets 
and liabilities at the date of the financial statements, and&#13;the reported 
amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Management reviews
these estimates and assumptions on&#13;an ongoing basis using currently 
available information. Actual results could differ from those estimates. 
&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; 
margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Income 
Tax&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; 
margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The company utilizes the liability method of 
accounting for income&#13;taxes. Under the liability method deferred tax assets 
and liabilities are determined based on the differences between 
financial&#13;reporting and the tax bases of the assets and liabilities and are 
measured using the enacted tax rates and laws that will be in&#13;effect, when 
the differences are expected to be reverse. An allowance against deferred tax 
assets is recorded, when it is more&#13;likely than not that such tax benefits 
will not be realized.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Since inception 
through June 30, 2013, the company had a net operating&#13;loss available for 
carry forward of $2,407,487.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Earnings Per 
Share&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; 
margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company follows ASC Topic 260 
to&#13;account for earnings per share. Basic earnings per common share 
(&amp;#147;EPS&amp;#148;) calculations are determined by dividing&#13;net income
by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the 
year. Diluted earnings per common&#13;share calculations are determined by 
dividing net income by the weighted average number of common shares and dilutive
common&#13;share equivalents outstanding. During periods when common stock 
equivalents, if any, are anti-dilutive they are not&#13;considered in the 
computation. Because the Company does not have any potentially dilutive 
securities, the accompanying&#13;presentation is only of basic loss per common 
share.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif;
margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Cash &amp;#38; Cash
Equivalents&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company considers all highly liquid 
investments with an original&#13;maturity of three months or less to be cash 
equivalents.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Impairment of Long-Lived 
Assets&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif;
margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company reviews and evaluates long-lived 
assets for impairment&#13;when events or changes in circumstances indicate that 
the related carrying amounts may not be recoverable. The assets are 
subject&#13;to impairment consideration under FASB ASC 360-10-35-17 if events or
circumstances indicate that their carrying amount might not&#13;be recoverable. 
When the Company determines that an impairment analysis should be done, the 
analysis will be performed using the&#13;rules of FASB ASC 930-360-35, Asset 
Impairment, and 360-10 through 15-5, Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived 
Assets.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Environmental 
Requirements&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;At the report date, environmental 
requirements related to a formally&#13;held mineral claim are unknown and 
therefore any estimate of future costs cannot be made.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Mineral Property Acquisitions 
Costs&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; 
margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Costs of acquisition and option costs of mineral 
rights are capitalized&#13;upon acquisition. Mine development costs incurred to 
develop new ore deposits, to expand the capacity of mines, or to develop 
mine&#13;areas substantially in advance of current production are also 
capitalized once proven and probable reserves exist and the property&#13;is a 
commercially mineable property.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Costs incurred to
maintain current production or to&#13;maintain assets on a standby basis are 
charged to operations. If the Company does not continue with exploration after 
the&#13;completion of the feasibility study, the mineral rights will be expensed
at that time. Costs of abandoned projects are&#13;charged to mining costs 
including related property and equipment costs. To determine if these costs are 
in excess of their&#13;recoverable amount periodic evaluation of carrying value 
of capitalized costs and any related property and equipment costs&#13;are based 
upon expected future cash flows and/or estimated salvage value in accordance 
with FASB Accounting Standards&#13;Codification (ASC) 360-10-35-15, Impairment 
or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/115% Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Various factors could impact our ability to achieve 
forecasted&#13;production schedules. Additionally, commodity prices, capital 
expenditure requirements and reclamation costs could differ&#13;from the 
assumptions the Company may use in cash flow models from exploration stage 
mineral interests. This, however,&#13;involves further risks in addition to 
those factors applicable to mineral interests where proven and probable reserves
have&#13;been identified, due to the lower level of confidence that the 
identified mineralized material can ultimately be 
mined&#13;economically.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Estimates and 
Assumptions&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Management uses estimates and 
assumptions in preparing financial&#13;statements in accordance with generally 
accepted accounting principles. Those estimates and assumptions affect the 
reported amounts&#13;of the assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent
assets and liabilities, and the reported revenues and expenses. 
Actual&#13;results could vary from the estimates that were assumed in preparing 
these financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Stock-based 
compensation&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company records stock based 
compensation to employees in accordance&#13;with the guidance in ASC Topic 718 
which requires the Company to recognize expenses related to the fair value of 
its employee stock&#13;option awards. This eliminates accounting for share-based
compensation transactions using the intrinsic value and requires 
instead&#13;that such transactions be accounted for using a fair-value-based 
method. The Company recognizes the cost of all share-based awards&#13;on a 
graded vesting basis over the vesting period of the 
award.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif;
margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company accounts for equity instruments 
issued in exchange&#13;for the receipt of goods or services from other than 
employees in accordance with FASB ASC 505-50 and the conclusions reached&#13;by 
the FASB ASC 505-50. Costs are measured at the estimated fair market value of 
the consideration received or the estimated&#13;fair value of the equity 
instruments issued, whichever is more reliably measurable. The value of equity 
instruments issued&#13;for consideration other than employee services is 
determined on the earliest of a performance commitment or completion 
of&#13;performance by the provider of goods or services as defined by FASB ASC 
505-50.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Fair value of financial 
instruments&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Fair value estimates discussed herein are
based upon certain&#13;market assumptions and pertinent information available to
management as of June 30, 2013 and December 31, 2012. The&#13;respective 
carrying value of certain on-balance-sheet financial instruments approximated 
their fair values. These financial&#13;instruments include cash, accounts 
payable and accrued liabilities and advances from related party. Fair values 
were assumed&#13;to approximate carrying values for cash, payables and advances 
from related party because they are short term in nature and&#13;their carrying 
amounts approximate fair values or they are payable on 
demand.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Level 1: The preferred inputs to 
valuation efforts are &amp;#34;quoted&#13;prices in active markets for identical
assets or liabilities,&amp;#34; with the caveat that the reporting entity must 
have access&#13;to that market. Information at this level is based on direct 
observations of transactions involving the same assets and liabilities,&#13;not 
assumptions, and thus offers superior reliability. However, relatively few 
items, especially physical assets, actually trade&#13;in active 
markets.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Level 2: FASB acknowledged that active 
markets for identical&#13;assets and liabilities are relatively uncommon and, 
even when they do exist, they may be too thin to provide 
reliable&#13;information. To deal with this shortage of direct data, the board 
provided a second level of inputs that can be applied in&#13;three 
situations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Level 3: If inputs from levels 1 and 2
are not available, FASB acknowledges&#13;that fair value measures of many assets
and liabilities are less precise. The board describes Level 3 inputs as 
&amp;#34;unobservable,&amp;#34;&#13;and limits their use by saying they 
&amp;#34;shall be used to measure fair value to the extent that observable 
inputs are not available.&amp;#34;&#13;This category allows &amp;#34;for 
situations in which there is little, if any, market activity for the asset or 
liability at the measurement&#13;date&amp;#34;.Earlier in the standard, FASB 
explains that &amp;#34;observable inputs&amp;#34; are gathered from sources 
other than the reporting&#13;company and that they are expected to reflect 
assumptions made by market participants.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Recent Accounting 
Pronouncements&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company has evaluated the 
recent accounting pronouncements and&#13;believes that none of them will have a 
material effect on the company's financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2013-01-01to2013-06-
30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Income 
Tax&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; 
margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The company utilizes the liability method of 
accounting for income&#13;taxes. Under the liability method deferred tax assets 
and liabilities are determined based on the differences between 
financial&#13;reporting and the tax bases of the assets and liabilities and are 
measured using the enacted tax rates and laws that will be in&#13;effect, when 
the differences are expected to be reverse. An allowance against deferred tax 
assets is recorded, when it is more&#13;likely than not that such tax benefits 
will not be realized.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Since inception 
through June 30, 2013, the company had a net operating&#13;loss available for 
carry forward of $2,407,487.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:EarningsPerSharePolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2013-01-01to2013-
06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;Earnings Per Share&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company 
follows ASC Topic 260 to&#13;account for earnings per share. Basic earnings per 
common share (&amp;#147;EPS&amp;#148;) calculations are determined by 
dividing&#13;net income by the weighted average number of shares of common stock
outstanding during the year. Diluted earnings per common&#13;share calculations 
are determined by dividing net income by the weighted average number of common 
shares and dilutive common&#13;share equivalents outstanding. During periods 
when common stock equivalents, if any, are anti-dilutive they are 
not&#13;considered in the computation. Because the Company does not have any 
potentially dilutive securities, the accompanying&#13;presentation is only of 
basic loss per common share.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:EarningsPerSharePolicyTextBlock>

    <us-gaap:BasisOfAccountingPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2013-01-
01to2013-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin:
0"&gt;Basis of Preparation&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Pursuant to the 
rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange&#13;Commission for Form 10-
Q, the financial statements, footnote disclosures and other information normally
included in financial statements&#13;prepared in accordance with generally 
accepted accounting principles have been condensed or omitted. The financial 
statements contained&#13;in this report are unaudited but, in the opinion of 
management, reflect all adjustments, consisting of only normal recurring 
adjustments,&#13;necessary for a fair presentation of the interim financial 
statements. The results of operations for any interim period are 
not&#13;necessarily indicative of results for the full year. The balance sheet 
as at December 31, 2012 has been derived from audited financial&#13;statements 
at that date but does not include all of the information and footnotes required 
by accounting principles generally accepted&#13;in the United States of America 
for complete financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The preparation of financial statements in 
conformity with accounting&#13;principles generally accepted in the United 
States requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the 
reported&#13;amounts of assets and liabilities, disclosure of contingent assets 
and liabilities at the date of the financial statements, and&#13;the reported 
amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Management reviews
these estimates and assumptions on&#13;an ongoing basis using currently 
available information. Actual results could differ from those estimates. 
&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:BasisOfAccountingPolicyPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:UseOfEstimates contextRef="From2013-01-01to2013-06-30">&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Estimates and 
Assumptions&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times,

in preparing financial&#13;statements in accordance with generally accepted 
accounting principles. Those estimates and assumptions affect the reported 
amounts&#13;of the assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent assets 
and liabilities, and the reported revenues and expenses. Actual&#13;results 
could vary from the estimates that were assumed in preparing these financial 
statements.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:UseOfEstimates>
    <us-
gaap:ShareBasedCompensationArrangementByShareBasedPaymentAwardPolicyForIssuingSh
aresUponExercise contextRef="From2013-01-01to2013-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt

New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company records stock based 
compensation to employees in accordance&#13;with the guidance in ASC Topic 718 
which requires the Company to recognize expenses related to the fair value of 
its employee stock&#13;option awards. This eliminates accounting for share-based
compensation transactions using the intrinsic value and requires 
instead&#13;that such transactions be accounted for using a fair-value-based 
method. The Company recognizes the cost of all share-based awards&#13;on a 
graded vesting basis over the vesting period of the 
award.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif;

issued in exchange&#13;for the receipt of goods or services from other than 
employees in accordance with FASB ASC 505-50 and the conclusions reached&#13;by 
the FASB ASC 505-50. Costs are measured at the estimated fair market value of 
the consideration received or the estimated&#13;fair value of the equity 
instruments issued, whichever is more reliably measurable. The value of equity 
instruments issued&#13;for consideration other than employee services is 
determined on the earliest of a performance commitment or completion 
of&#13;performance by the provider of goods or services as defined by FASB ASC 
505-50.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:ShareBasedCompensationArrangementByShareBasedPaymentAwardPolicyForIssuingSh

    <us-gaap:FairValueMeasurementPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2013-01-
01to2013-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;Fair value of financial instruments&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Fair value estimates discussed herein are based upon
certain&#13;market assumptions and pertinent information available to management
as of June 30, 2013 and December 31, 2012. The&#13;respective carrying value of 
certain on-balance-sheet financial instruments approximated their fair values. 
These financial&#13;instruments include cash, accounts payable and accrued 
liabilities and advances from related party. Fair values were assumed&#13;to 
approximate carrying values for cash, payables and advances from related party 
because they are short term in nature and&#13;their carrying amounts approximate
fair values or they are payable on demand.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font:
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Level 1: The preferred inputs to valuation efforts 
are &amp;#34;quoted&#13;prices in active markets for identical assets or 
liabilities,&amp;#34; with the caveat that the reporting entity must have 
access&#13;to that market. Information at this level is based on direct 
observations of transactions involving the same assets and liabilities,&#13;not 
assumptions, and thus offers superior reliability. However, relatively few 
items, especially physical assets, actually trade&#13;in active 
markets.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Level 2: FASB acknowledged that active 
markets for identical&#13;assets and liabilities are relatively uncommon and, 
even when they do exist, they may be too thin to provide 
reliable&#13;information. To deal with this shortage of direct data, the board 
provided a second level of inputs that can be applied in&#13;three 
situations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Level 3: If inputs from levels 1 and 2 
are not available, FASB acknowledges&#13;that fair value measures of many assets
and liabilities are less precise. The board describes Level 3 inputs as 
&amp;#34;unobservable,&amp;#34;&#13;and limits their use by saying they 
&amp;#34;shall be used to measure fair value to the extent that observable 
inputs are not available.&amp;#34;&#13;This category allows &amp;#34;for 
situations in which there is little, if any, market activity for the asset or 
liability at the measurement&#13;date&amp;#34;.Earlier in the standard, FASB 
explains that &amp;#34;observable inputs&amp;#34; are gathered from sources 
other than the reporting&#13;company and that they are expected to reflect 
assumptions made by market participants.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:FairValueMeasurementPolicyPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:EquityMethodInvestmentsDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2013-01-
01to2013-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;4. JOINT VENTURE&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif;
margin: 0"&gt;On June 17, 2013, the Company entered into a &lt;i&gt;Processing 
Lease&#13;and Option To Purchase Agreement&lt;/i&gt;, thereby effecting the 
&lt;i&gt;Joint Venture Agreement&lt;/i&gt;, dated May 30, 2013, 
(collectively,&#13;the &amp;#147;Agreements&amp;#148;) with CGrowth Capital, 
Inc., a Delaware corporation (&amp;#34;CGrowth&amp;#34;). Pursuant to the 
Agreements,&#13;CGrowth is obligated to provide operational, on-site, and sales 
support in respect to the Chewelah Community Pit, a 15 acre sand&#13;and gravel 
pit in Colville,Washington. A copy of the approved Bureau of Land Management 
(&amp;#147;BLM&amp;#148;) &lt;i&gt;Contract For The&#13;Sale Of Mineral 
Materials&lt;/i&gt; and all the Agreements were attached to our report on Form 
8-K dated June 19, 2013. According to&#13;the terms of the Agreements, the 
Company is obligated to make an initial payment of $50,000, followed by a
payment of $300,000&#13;in 30 days or less. As of June 30, 2013, $59,617 has 
been paid by the company and is recorded as Mineral Rights on the 
Balance&#13;Sheet. These Mineral Rights are part of the Joint Venture. To date, 
$175,000 has been paid by the Company which was financed by&#13;related party 
advances. Also, the Company shall be entitled to 51% of the net revenue, and 
CGrowth shall be entitled to 49% of&#13;the net revenue respectively. A separate
DBA was created to operate the Joint Venture and all transactions have been 
recorded under&#13;JPX Global. The Joint Venture Agreement expires on June 1, 
2014, but will automatically extend for an additional year, in 
anticipation&#13;of a 5-year BLM extension. The copies of the Agreements are 
provided as exhibits to our Form 8-K dated June19, 2013.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:EquityMethodInvestmentsDisclosureTextBlock>
    <JPEX:AcquisitionOfMineralClaimTextBlock contextRef="From2013-01-01to2013-
06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;5. 
ACQUISITION OF A MINERAL CLAIM&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;During 2010 the 
company acquired mineral claims for $15,000 known&#13;as the Red Streak Jasper 
Property, located about three (3) kilometers southwest of the town of Westwold, 
British Columbia, Canada&#13;consisting of two (2) claim units consisting of a 
total of 12 cells located about three (3) kilometers southwest of the town 
of&#13;Westwold, British Columbia, Canada. The total claim area is 247.45 
hectares.&lt;font style="color: black"&gt; We intend to continue&#13;to hold the
mining claims, but will not be developing these assets during 2013. For this 
reason, we are no longer classifying&#13;the Company as an exploration stage 
company. The primary goal of the Company will be to develop into a waste 
services business&#13;and classify the Company as a development stage 
company.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The acquisitions 
costs have been impaired and expensed during 2010&#13;because there had been no 
exploration activities nor had there been any reserves established and we could 
not project any future&#13;cash flows or salvage value and the acquisition costs
were not recoverable. Consequently, we have recorded an impairment loss 
for&#13;the full amount of $15,091 during the year ended December 31, 
2010.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; 
margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;On June 7, 2013, the Company acquired mineral
rights to the&#13;Chewelah Community Pit, a 15 acre sand and gravel pit in 
Colville, Washington through its joint venture with CGrowth Capital,&#13;Inc. A 
copy of the approved Bureau of Land Management (&amp;#147;BLM&amp;#148;) 
&lt;i&gt;Contract For The Sale Of Mineral Materials&lt;/i&gt;&#13;and all the 
Agreements were attached to our report on form 8-K dated June 19, 
2013.&lt;/p&gt;</JPEX:AcquisitionOfMineralClaimTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:DebtDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2013-01-01to2013-06-
30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;6. 
CONVERTIBLE NOTE&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;On December 18, 2008, the 
company entered into a Promissory Note&#13;agreement with the then CEO of the 
Company. The note was for a sum of $1,500 non interest bearing, due and payable 
on December&#13;31, 2010. If note is not paid on December 31, 2010, the note can
be converted to common stock of the Company for $.001 per share.&#13;At the time
the note was issued, the Company did not have a fair value for the stock 
therefore no beneficial conversion feature&#13;exists. At this time, the Company
and the debt holder have not converted the loan into shares of the Company, and 
the Company does&#13;not currently plan to. The Company and the note holder have
verbally agreed that the Company will pay the loan off as it is able&#13;to 
without penalty. As of June 30, 2013 and December 31, 2012, the balance in note 
payable account is $1,500.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:DebtDisclosureTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:StockholdersEquityNoteDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2013-01-
01to2013-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;7. CAPITAL STOCK&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;On August 31, 
2010, the company issued 30,000,000 private placement&#13;common shares to its 
founder for cash of $30,000.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif;
margin: 0"&gt;On August 17, 2011 the Company issued 100,000 common shares at 
par&#13;value to its transfer agent for services 
rendered.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;On February 15, 2013, the 
Company entered into an agreement to acquire&#13;all of the outstanding shares 
of Scorpex, Inc., a Nevada corporation (hereafter, &amp;#147;Scorpex&amp;#148;),
in exchange for 103,250,000&#13;shares of Common Stock and 5,000,000 shares of 
Series A Preferred Stock of the Company (such transaction is hereafter 
referred&#13;to as the &amp;#147;Acquisition&amp;#148;). A material condition of
the Acquisition, production of audited financial statements, has&#13;not been 
provided by Scorpex and therefore the Acquisition was terminated in accordance 
with its terms. All stock issuances have&#13;been rescinded associated with the 
Acquisition and the total issued and outstanding stock of the Company is 
30,100,000 shares of&#13;common stock and 0 shares of preferred stock. No 
termination penalties have been incurred by the 
Company.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;On June 19, 2013 the Company issued 
1,875,000 common shares&#13;valued at $2,343,750 for services rendered to 
Southbay Holdings and its affiliates. These consultants received their 
shares&#13;for organizing the joint venture with CGrowth and with the 
preparation for other acquisition, merger, and joint 
venture&#13;partners.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:StockholdersEquityNoteDisclosureTextBlock>

      <link:presentationArc order="20"

      <link:loc xlink:type="locator" xlink:href="jpex-

      <link:presentationArc order="30"

      <link:loc xlink:type="locator" xlink:href="http://xbrl.fasb.org/us-

      <link:presentationArc order="40"

      <link:loc xlink:type="locator" xlink:href="http://xbrl.fasb.org/us-

    </link:presentationLink>
    <link:presentationLink xlink:type="extended"

      <link:loc xlink:type="locator" xlink:href="http://xbrl.fasb.org/us-

ZeroAsNone>false</DisplayZeroAsNone><NumericAmount>0</NumericAmount><RoundedNume
ricAmount>0</RoundedNumericAmount><NonNumbericText>&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;3. SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING
POLICIES&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Basis of 
Preparation&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Pursuant to
the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange
Commission for Form 10-Q, the financial statements, footnote disclosures and 
other information normally included in financial statements
prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles have been 
condensed or omitted. The financial statements contained
in this report are unaudited but, in the opinion of management, reflect all 
adjustments, consisting of only normal recurring adjustments,
necessary for a fair presentation of the interim financial statements. The 
results of operations for any interim period are not
necessarily indicative of results for the full year. The balance sheet as at 
December 31, 2012 has been derived from audited financial
statements at that date but does not include all of the information and 
footnotes required by accounting principles generally accepted
in the United States of America for complete financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The 
preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States requires management to make 
estimates and assumptions that affect the reported
amounts of assets and liabilities, disclosure of contingent assets and 
liabilities at the date of the financial statements, and
the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. 
Management reviews these estimates and assumptions on
an ongoing basis using currently available information. Actual results could 
differ from those estimates. &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Income 
Tax&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The company
utilizes the liability method of accounting for income
taxes. Under the liability method deferred tax assets and liabilities are 
determined based on the differences between financial
reporting and the tax bases of the assets and liabilities and are measured using
the enacted tax rates and laws that will be in
effect, when the differences are expected to be reverse. An allowance against
deferred tax assets is recorded, when it is more
likely than not that such tax benefits will not be realized.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Since 
inception through June 30, 2013, the company had a net operating
loss available for carry forward of $2,407,487.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Earnings 
Per Share&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company
follows ASC Topic 260 to
account for earnings per share. Basic earnings per common share 
(&amp;#147;EPS&amp;#148;) calculations are determined by dividing
net income by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding 
during the year. Diluted earnings per common
share calculations are determined by dividing net income by the weighted average
number of common shares and dilutive common
share equivalents outstanding. During periods when common stock equivalents, if 
any, are anti-dilutive they are not
considered in the computation. Because the Company does not have any potentially
dilutive securities, the accompanying
presentation is only of basic loss per common share.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Cash 
&amp;#38; Cash Equivalents&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company
considers all highly liquid investments with an original
maturity of three months or less to be cash equivalents.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Impairment 
of Long-Lived Assets&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company
reviews and evaluates long-lived assets for impairment
when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the related carrying 
amounts may not be recoverable. The assets are subject
to impairment consideration under FASB ASC 360-10-35-17 if events or 
circumstances indicate that their carrying amount might not
be recoverable. When the Company determines that an impairment analysis should 
be done, the analysis will be performed using the
rules of FASB ASC 930-360-35, Asset Impairment, and 360-10 through 15-5,
Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;Environmental Requirements&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;At the 
report date, environmental requirements related to a formally
held mineral claim are unknown and therefore any estimate of future costs cannot
be made.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Mineral 
Property Acquisitions Costs&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
center"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Costs of 
acquisition and option costs of mineral rights are capitalized
upon acquisition. Mine development costs incurred to develop new ore deposits, 
to expand the capacity of mines, or to develop mine
areas substantially in advance of current production are also capitalized once 
proven and probable reserves exist and the property
is a commercially mineable property.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Costs 
incurred to maintain current production or to
maintain assets on a standby basis are charged to operations. If the Company 
does not continue with exploration after the
completion of the feasibility study, the mineral rights will be expensed at that
time. Costs of abandoned projects are
charged to mining costs including related property and equipment costs. To 
determine if these costs are in excess of their
recoverable amount periodic evaluation of carrying value of capitalized costs 
and any related property and equipment costs
are based upon expected future cash flows and/or estimated salvage value in 
accordance with FASB Accounting Standards
Codification (ASC) 360-10-35-15, Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived 
Assets.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt/115% Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Various 
factors could impact our ability to achieve forecasted
production schedules. Additionally, commodity prices, capital expenditure
requirements and reclamation costs could differ
from the assumptions the Company may use in cash flow models from exploration 
stage mineral interests. This, however,
involves further risks in addition to those factors applicable to mineral 
interests where proven and probable reserves have
been identified, due to the lower level of confidence that the identified 
mineralized material can ultimately be mined
economically.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Estimates 
and Assumptions&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Management 
uses estimates and assumptions in preparing financial
statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. Those 
estimates and assumptions affect the reported amounts
of the assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent assets and 
liabilities, and the reported revenues and expenses. Actual
results could vary from the estimates that were assumed in preparing these 
financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Stock-based
compensation&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company
records stock based compensation to employees in accordance
with the guidance in ASC Topic 718 which requires the Company to recognize 
expenses related to the fair value of its employee stock
option awards. This eliminates accounting for share-based compensation 
transactions using the intrinsic value and requires instead
that such transactions be accounted for using a fair-value-based method. The 
Company recognizes the cost of all share-based awards
on a graded vesting basis over the vesting period of the award.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company
accounts for equity instruments issued in exchange
for the receipt of goods or services from other than employees in accordance 
with FASB ASC 505-50 and the conclusions reached
by the FASB ASC 505-50. Costs are measured at the estimated fair market value of
the consideration received or the estimated
fair value of the equity instruments issued, whichever is more reliably 
measurable. The value of equity instruments issued
for consideration other than employee services is determined on the earliest of 
a performance commitment or completion of
performance by the provider of goods or services as defined by FASB ASC 505-
50.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Fair value 
of financial instruments&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Fair value 
estimates discussed herein are based upon certain
market assumptions and pertinent information available to management as of June 
30, 2013 and December 31, 2012. The
respective carrying value of certain on-balance-sheet financial instruments 
approximated their fair values. These financial
instruments include cash, accounts payable and accrued liabilities and advances 
from related party. Fair values were assumed
to approximate carrying values for cash, payables and advances from related 
party because they are short term in nature and
their carrying amounts approximate fair values or they are payable on 
demand.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Level 1: 
The preferred inputs to valuation efforts are &amp;#34;quoted
prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities,&amp;#34; with the 
caveat that the reporting entity must have access
to that market. Information at this level is based on direct observations of 
transactions involving the same assets and liabilities,
not assumptions, and thus offers superior reliability. However, relatively few 
items, especially physical assets, actually trade
in active markets.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Level 2: 
FASB acknowledged that active markets for identical
assets and liabilities are relatively uncommon and, even when they do exist, 
they may be too thin to provide reliable
information. To deal with this shortage of direct data, the board provided a 
second level of inputs that can be applied in
three situations.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Level 3: If
inputs from levels 1 and 2 are not available, FASB acknowledges
that fair value measures of many assets and liabilities are less precise. The 
board describes Level 3 inputs as &amp;#34;unobservable,&amp;#34;
and limits their use by saying they &amp;#34;shall be used to measure fair value
to the extent that observable inputs are not available.&amp;#34;
This category allows &amp;#34;for situations in which there is little, if any, 
market activity for the asset or liability at the measurement
date&amp;#34;.Earlier in the standard, FASB explains that &amp;#34;observable 
inputs&amp;#34; are gathered from sources other than the reporting
company and that they are expected to reflect assumptions made by market 
participants.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;Recent
Accounting Pronouncements&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company
has evaluated the recent accounting pronouncements and
believes that none of them will have a material effect on the company's 
financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;</NonNumbericText><FootnoteIndexer 
/><CurrencyCode /><CurrencySymbol 
/><IsIndependantCurrency>false</IsIndependantCurrency><ShowCurrencySymbol>false<
/ShowCurrencySymbol><DisplayDateInUSFormat>false</DisplayDateInUSFormat></Cell><
/Cells><ElementDataType>nonnum:textBlockItemType</ElementDataType><SimpleDataTyp
e>na</SimpleDataType><ElementDefenition>The entire disclosure for all 
significant accounting policies of the reporting 
entity.</ElementDefenition><ElementReferences>Reference 1: 
http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef

</LabelSeparator><Level>2</Level><ElementName>us-

ZeroAsNone>false</DisplayZeroAsNone><NumericAmount>0</NumericAmount><RoundedNume
ricAmount>0</RoundedNumericAmount><NonNumbericText>&lt;p style="font: 10pt/115% 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 10pt"&gt;1. ORGANIZATION&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The company
was incorporated under the laws of the state of Nevada
on December 18, 2008, with 75,000,000 authorized common shares with a par value
of $0.001. On January 3, 2013, the Company approved
the action to amend and restate the Articles of Incorporation of the Company and
increase the authorized common shares to 500,000,000
and create and authorize 40,000,000 shares of Preferred Stock which was approved
by written consent of the holders representing
approximately 67% of the outstanding voting securities of the Company. Series A 
Preferred Stock was created and designated with
super-voting rights of 100 votes per share of Series A Preferred Stock held, and
is convertible into 10 shares of common stock
for every share of preferred stock held.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company
was initially organized for the purpose of acquiring
and exploring mineral claims. The company acquired a mineral claim with unknown 
reserves. We intend to continue to hold the mining
claims, but will not be developing these assets during 2013.&amp;#160; For this 
reason, we are no longer classifying the Company as
an exploration stage company.&amp;#160; The Company has entered the sand and 
gravel extraction business with its joint venture in the
state of Washington and expects to receive revenue from the joint venture during
the 2013 fiscal year.&amp;#160; The future goal of
the Company will be to develop a waste services division&amp;#160; The Company 
has modified its business plan to include the development
of waste management services including the storage, recycling, and disposal of 
waste.&amp;#160; The Company does not presently have
any waste management operations and is considered to be in the development 
stage, but due to our joint venture we expect to have
revenues and adjust our classification as a development stage company to an 
operational stage company as sales are 
made.&lt;/p&gt;</NonNumbericText><FootnoteIndexer /><CurrencyCode

        <tr>
          <td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.hideAR();">X</a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td>
            <div class="body" style="padding: 2px;"><a 
href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">- 
Definition</a><div>
                <p>Amount of income (loss) from continuing operations 
attributable to the parent. Also defined as revenue less expenses and taxes from
ongoing operations before extraordinary items but after deduction of those 
portions of income or loss from continuing operations that are allocable to 
noncontrolling interests.</p>
              </div><a href="javascript:void(0);" 
onclick="top.Show.toggleNext( this );">+ References</a><div style="display:

                  </tr>

                    <td><strong> Period Type:</strong></td>
                    <td>duration</td>
                  </tr>
                </table>
              </div>
            </div>
          </td>
        </tr>
      </table>

  <head>
    <META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=us-ascii">
    <link rel="StyleSheet" type="text/css" href="report.css"><script 
type="text/javascript" src="Show.js">/* Do Not Remove This Comment 
*/</script></head>
  <body><span style="display: none;">v2.4.0.8</span><table class="report" 
border="0" cellspacing="2" id="ID0ELE">
      <tr>
        <th class="tl" colspan="1" rowspan="2">
          <div style="width: 200px;"><strong>5. ACQUISITION OF A MINERAL 
CLAIM<br></strong></div>
        </th>
        <th class="th" colspan="1">6 Months Ended</th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <th class="th">
          <div>Jun. 30, 2013</div>
        </th>
      </tr>
      <tr class="re">
        <td class="pl" style="border-bottom: 0px;" valign="top"><a class="a" 
href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.showAR( this, 
'defref_JPEX_NotesToFinancialStatementsAbstract', window );"><strong>Notes to 
Financial Statements</strong></a></td>
        <td class="text">&#xA0;<span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="ro">
        <td class="pl" style="border-bottom: 0px;" valign="top"><a class="a" 
href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.showAR( this, 
'defref_JPEX_AcquisitionOfMineralClaimTextBlock', window );">5. ACQUISITION OF A
MINERAL CLAIM</a></td>
        <td class="text"><p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; 
margin: 0">5. ACQUISITION OF A MINERAL CLAIM</p>
<p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&#160;</p>
<p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">During 2010 the 
company acquired mineral claims for $15,000 known
as the Red Streak Jasper Property, located about three (3) kilometers southwest 
of the town of Westwold, British Columbia, Canada
consisting of two (2) claim units consisting of a total of 12 cells located 
about three (3) kilometers southwest of the town of
Westwold, British Columbia, Canada. The total claim area is 247.45 
hectares.<font style="color: black"> We intend to continue
to hold the mining claims, but will not be developing these assets during 2013. 
For this reason, we are no longer classifying
the Company as an exploration stage company. The primary goal of the Company 
will be to develop into a waste services business
and classify the Company as a development stage company.</font></p>
<p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&#160;</p>
<p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">The acquisitions 
costs have been impaired and expensed during 2010
because there had been no exploration activities nor had there been any reserves
established and we could not project any future
cash flows or salvage value and the acquisition costs were not recoverable. 
Consequently, we have recorded an impairment loss for
the full amount of $15,091 during the year ended December 31, 2010.</p>
<p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&#160;</p>
<p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">On June 7, 2013, 
the Company acquired mineral rights to the
Chewelah Community Pit, a 15 acre sand and gravel pit in Colville, Washington 
through its joint venture with CGrowth Capital,
Inc. A copy of the approved Bureau of Land Management (&#147;BLM&#148;) 
<i>Contract For The Sale Of Mineral Materials</i>
and all the Agreements were attached to our report on form 8-K dated June 19, 
2013.</p><span></span></td>
      </tr>
    </table>
    <div style="display: none;">
      <table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="authRefData" 
style="display: none;" id="defref_JPEX_AcquisitionOfMineralClaimTextBlock">
        <tr>
          <td class="hide"><a style="color: white;" href="javascript:void(0);"

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>XML
<SEQUENCE>13
<FILENAME>Show.js
<DESCRIPTION>IDEA: XBRL DOCUMENT
<TEXT>
/**
 * Rivet Software Inc.
 *
 * @copyright Copyright (c) 2006-2011 Rivet Software, Inc. All rights reserved.
 * Version 2.4.0.3
 *
 */
var Show = {};
Show.LastAR = null,
Show.hideAR = function(){
Show.LastAR.style.display = 'none';
};
Show.showAR = function ( link, id, win ){
if( Show.LastAR ){
Show.hideAR();
}
var ref = link;
do {
ref = ref.nextSibling;
} while (ref && ref.nodeName != 'TABLE');
if (!ref || ref.nodeName != 'TABLE') {
var tmp = win ?
win.document.getElementById(id) :
document.getElementById(id);
if( tmp ){
ref = tmp.cloneNode(true);
ref.id = '';
link.parentNode.appendChild(ref);
}
}
if( ref ){
ref.style.display = 'block';
Show.LastAR = ref;
}
};
Show.toggleNext = function( link ){
var ref = link;
do{
ref = ref.nextSibling;
}while( ref.nodeName != 'DIV' );
if( ref.style &&
ref.style.display &&
ref.style.display == 'none' ){
ref.style.display = 'block';
if( link.textContent ){
link.textContent = link.textContent.replace( '+', '-' );
}else{
link.innerText = link.innerText.replace( '+', '-' );
}
}else{
ref.style.display = 'none';
if( link.textContent ){
link.textContent = link.textContent.replace( '-', '+' );
}else{
link.innerText = link.innerText.replace( '-', '+' );
}
}
};
</TEXT>
</DOCUMENT>

ZeroAsNone>false</DisplayZeroAsNone><NumericAmount>0</NumericAmount><RoundedNume
ricAmount>0</RoundedNumericAmount><NonNumbericText>&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;4. JOINT VENTURE&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;On June 17,
2013, the Company entered into a &lt;i&gt;Processing Lease
and Option To Purchase Agreement&lt;/i&gt;, thereby effecting the &lt;i&gt;Joint
Venture Agreement&lt;/i&gt;, dated May 30, 2013, (collectively,
the &amp;#147;Agreements&amp;#148;) with CGrowth Capital, Inc., a Delaware 
corporation (&amp;#34;CGrowth&amp;#34;). Pursuant to the Agreements,
CGrowth is obligated to provide operational, on-site, and sales support in 
respect to the Chewelah Community Pit, a 15 acre sand
and gravel pit in Colville,Washington. A copy of the approved Bureau of Land 
Management (&amp;#147;BLM&amp;#148;) &lt;i&gt;Contract For The
Sale Of Mineral Materials&lt;/i&gt; and all the Agreements were attached to our
report on Form 8-K dated June 19, 2013. According to
the terms of the Agreements, the Company is obligated to make an initial payment
of $50,000, followed by a payment of $300,000
in 30 days or less. As of June 30, 2013, $59,617 has been paid by the company 
and is recorded as Mineral Rights on the Balance
Sheet. These Mineral Rights are part of the Joint Venture. To date, $175,000 has
been paid by the Company which was financed by
related party advances. Also, the Company shall be entitled to 51% of the net 
revenue, and CGrowth shall be entitled to 49% of
the net revenue respectively. A separate DBA was created to operate the Joint 
Venture and all transactions have been recorded under
JPX Global. The Joint Venture Agreement expires on June 1, 2014, but will 
automatically extend for an additional year, in anticipation
of a 5-year BLM extension. The copies of the Agreements are provided as exhibits
to our Form 8-K dated June19, 
2013.&lt;/p&gt;</NonNumbericText><FootnoteIndexer /><CurrencyCode 
/><CurrencySymbol 
/><IsIndependantCurrency>false</IsIndependantCurrency><ShowCurrencySymbol>false<
/ShowCurrencySymbol><DisplayDateInUSFormat>false</DisplayDateInUSFormat></Cell><
/Cells><ElementDataType>nonnum:textBlockItemType</ElementDataType><SimpleDataTyp
e>na</SimpleDataType><ElementDefenition>The entire disclosure for equity method 
investments and joint ventures. Equity method investments are investments that 
give the investor the ability to exercise significant influence over the 
operating and financial policies of an investee. Joint ventures are entities 
owned and operated by a small group of businesses as a separate and specific 
business or project for the mutual benefit of the members of the 
group.</ElementDefenition><ElementReferences>Reference 1: 
http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef

New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;7. CAPITAL STOCK&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;On August 
31, 2010, the company issued 30,000,000 private placement
common shares to its founder for cash of $30,000.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;On August 
17, 2011 the Company issued 100,000 common shares at par
value to its transfer agent for services rendered.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;On February
15, 2013, the Company entered into an agreement to acquire
all of the outstanding shares of Scorpex, Inc., a Nevada corporation (hereafter,
&amp;#147;Scorpex&amp;#148;), in exchange for 103,250,000
shares of Common Stock and 5,000,000 shares of Series A Preferred Stock of the 
Company (such transaction is hereafter referred
to as the &amp;#147;Acquisition&amp;#148;). A material condition of the 
Acquisition, production of audited financial statements, has
not been provided by Scorpex and therefore the Acquisition was terminated in 
accordance with its terms. All stock issuances have
been rescinded associated with the Acquisition and the total issued and 
outstanding stock of the Company is 30,100,000 shares of
common stock and 0 shares of preferred stock. No termination penalties have been
incurred by the Company.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 
0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;On June 19,
2013 the Company issued 1,875,000 common shares
valued at $2,343,750 for services rendered to Southbay Holdings and its 
affiliates. These consultants received their shares
for organizing the joint venture with CGrowth and with the preparation for other
acquisition, merger, and joint venture
partners.&lt;/p&gt;</NonNumbericText><FootnoteIndexer /><CurrencyCode

noncontrolling interest, including other comprehensive income. Includes, but is

-URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&amp;oid=6928386&amp;loc=d3e21484-112644

<html>
  <head>
    <META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=us-ascii">
    <link rel="StyleSheet" type="text/css" href="report.css"><script 
type="text/javascript" src="Show.js">/* Do Not Remove This Comment 
*/</script></head>
  <body><span style="display: none;">v2.4.0.8</span><table class="report" 
border="0" cellspacing="2" id="ID0ELE">
      <tr>
        <th class="tl" colspan="1" rowspan="2">
          <div style="width: 200px;"><strong>1. ORGANIZATION<br></strong></div>
        </th>
        <th class="th" colspan="1">6 Months Ended</th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <th class="th">
          <div>Jun. 30, 2013</div>
        </th>
      </tr>
      <tr class="re">
        <td class="pl" style="border-bottom: 0px;" valign="top"><a class="a" 
href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.showAR( this, 'defref_us-
gaap_OrganizationConsolidationAndPresentationOfFinancialStatementsAbstract', 
window );"><strong>Organization, Consolidation and Presentation of Financial 
Statements [Abstract]</strong></a></td>
        <td class="text">&#xA0;<span></span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="ro">
        <td class="pl" style="border-bottom: 0px;" valign="top"><a class="a" 
href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="top.Show.showAR( this, 'defref_us-
gaap_OrganizationConsolidationAndPresentationOfFinancialStatementsDisclosureText
Block', window );">1. ORGANIZATION</a></td>
        <td class="text"><p style="font: 10pt/115% Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0 0 10pt">1. ORGANIZATION</p>
<p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">The company was 
incorporated under the laws of the state of Nevada
on December 18, 2008, with 75,000,000 authorized common shares with a par value 
of $0.001. On January 3, 2013, the Company approved
the action to amend and restate the Articles of Incorporation of the Company and
increase the authorized common shares to 500,000,000
and create and authorize 40,000,000 shares of Preferred Stock which was approved
by written consent of the holders representing
approximately 67% of the outstanding voting securities of the Company. Series A 
Preferred Stock was created and designated with
super-voting rights of 100 votes per share of Series A Preferred Stock held, and
is convertible into 10 shares of common stock
for every share of preferred stock held.</p>
<p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 
0.5in">&#160;</p>
<p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">The Company was 
initially organized for the purpose of acquiring
and exploring mineral claims. The company acquired a mineral claim with unknown 
reserves. We intend to continue to hold the mining
claims, but will not be developing these assets during 2013.&#160; For this 
reason, we are no longer classifying the Company as
an exploration stage company.&#160; The Company has entered the sand and gravel 
extraction business with its joint venture in the
state of Washington and expects to receive revenue from the joint venture during
the 2013 fiscal year.&#160; The future goal of
the Company will be to develop a waste services division&#160; The Company has 
modified its business plan to include the development
of waste management services including the storage, recycling, and disposal of 
waste.&#160; The Company does not presently have
any waste management operations and is considered to be in the development 
stage, but due to our joint venture we expect to have
revenues and adjust our classification as a development stage company to an 
operational stage company as sales are made.</p><span></span></td>
      </tr>
    </table>
    <div style="display: none;">
